page.title: 04SEA DEFENCES BRISTOL CHANNEL
page.content: This part of the coast was constantly eroded by a scouring tide which rises to more than thirty feet. The shore is protected between Clevedon and Weston Super Mare by a double bank or sea wall. The inner bank which is a very old one was not an adequate protection when tides were particularly high or in storm conditions .History relates some very spectacular inundations, the worst was in 1606 when many people drowned and the water lay to a depth of 5 feet for ten days. The outer sea wall was constructed at the end of the Second World War by prisoner of war labour and is a rock and concrete construction which only fails to stop flooding on very rare occasions,and means that animals can use the pastures all the year round.
